title-group.article-title: Operating Experience and Economic Assessment of Small Wind Turbine Generators in the United Kingdom

abstract.p: This study comprises an updated and extended version of the paper presented at the Tenth Annual Conference of the British Wind Energy Association held at the CEGB headquarters in London on 23-25 March 1988. In the UK interest in wind generated energy is focused on large utility owned wind turbine generators (WTGs). Operating experience on commercially produced and privately owned small grid-connected WTGs has been very limited. This study describes experience in the private sector with owning, running and maintaining four WTGSs over the last 3-5 years. The economics of owning the systems have been considered from the owners' point of view. The structure of electricity tariffs and direct utilisation of wind generated electricity override many other considerations including a high wind regime location, higher buyback rates by the electricity authorities and better WTG performance. Local authority rates (property tax) are a severe penalty for non-agricultural WTG owners.
